utterances: This is an e-mail we just received from Celeste(ph) in Sacramento.
It says I'm a physician working with children in foster care or who are newly removed from their families due to abuse.
I'm also a generic child and adult psychiatrist.
And she says, unfortunately, there's never a lack of this work on holidays as well as on every other day and night of the year.
I'm Jewish so I always volunteer to be on-call on Christmas, she writes.
It's helpful to my colleagues and extra meaningful to the kids.
And as a bonus, it's a great time to catch up on the backlog of paperwork.
Well, here is another caller.
This is Greg(ph) in Bend, Oregon.
Greg, what are you doing this Christmas?
Well, I'm running printing presses.
Running printing presses.
Tell us more.
Well, basically, I have a little job that comes up.
It's a directory at the end of each year.
And there's a little window of opportunity between Christmas and New Years to get it to the binder so that they can get it to people for the first of the year.
And as is often the case, people basically procrastinate and don't get the stuff to you until the last minute, so it isn't like you have much of a life of your own when it comes to deadlines.
So you're one of those people who does not prefer to work on Christmas.
Well, I don't really prefer to work on Christmas.
Christmas isn't like a large looming thing to me than it is for a lot of people, I suppose.
Anything special that you do to mark today despite your having to be in the office?
(Soundbite of laughter)
I try to work in a relaxed manner as much as possible.
(Soundbite of laughter)
All right.
Well, good luck with that, Greg.
And thanks a lot for your call.
You bet.
Okay.
This is Keith(ph) in Jacksonville now.
Keith, hi.
Calling from a warm location, celebrating Christmas in Jacksonville, Florida.
How are you spending the day?
I am actually painting a mural today.
Painting a mural.
Yeah.
Outdoors?
Actually, in my barn.
In your barn?
Tell me more.
Yeah.
I have a studio shed up in my barn.
And I work out of the house, and I've got a deadline.
I got a mural that needs to be done by tomorrow.
So…
I don't suppose it's a Christmas-themed mural.
What's the content?
It's actually - I paint murals for a national chain of sub shops, in Firehouse subs.
And all of the murals are fire-themed in some way.
And this is a forest fire with deer jumping around and a guy in a big truck trying to put it out and all that kind of stuff.
All right.
Well, thanks for calling.
Good luck.
I hope you make your deadline, and have a merry Christmas.
Thank you very much.
Well, you may be relaxing at home with friends and family, but we're on the clock and we're talking shop.
So if you're working on Christmas, give us a call at 1-800-989-8255.
Or you could also send us an e-mail at talk@npr.org.
I'm Ari Shapiro and it's TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Ari Shapiro in Washington.
It's Christmas Day and you've probably already found the coffee shop in your neighborhood that's open today.
We wanted to know who else is working this Christmas?
We'd like to here from you if you are.
Take a break from the job and give us a call at 1-800-989-8255.
Or you can e-mail us at talk@npr.org or check out our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
And joining us now is a voice that some of you may be familiar with.
(Soundbite of archived newscast)
From NPR News in Washington, I'm Paul Brown.
Christians around the world are celebrating the birth of their savior today inside Saint…
Paul Brown works the morning shift for the newscast here at NPR this morning.
He joins us from his home here in Washington, D.C.
Paul, thanks for taking time out of your Christmas Day to be on the show.
Hi, Ari.
Fun to be here.
How many years have you been working on Christmas?
Gosh, you know, I probably did most of the last 25 years at small market radio stations, at different jobs.
You know, I worked one year at a ski resort, in the snack bar on Christmas Day and there were lots of people there.
And then at NPR, I've worked most of my eight years on Christmas Day and on New Year's Day and also on Thanksgiving.
Well, it sort of comes as part of my job.
At the newscast unit, I'm what's called a floater, and my job is to do everything whenever it's needed.
So that it is part of the job.
But I suppose I could ask off if I wanted to.
I really never do.
I did for my 20th wedding anniversary at Thanksgiving last year.
But that was the only time that I've really asked off.
So I actually kind of enjoy this.
What do you enjoy about it, specifically?
Well, let's see.
There's a small crew of us that's kind of like a bunch of rats running around the barn at NPR super early in the morning.
(Soundbite of laughter)
How else can I describe it?
I've been there.
I can attest to that.
Exactly.
We're sort of loyal to the job.
And another odd aspect of this, you know, public radio is very much a public service job.
And you've got to be sort of into that aspect of that, I think, to do it.
And I rather enjoy being there for people who tune in their radios or go on to the Web and find NPR and wouldn't mind hearing a familiar voice on a holiday when they're off.
But you know, there's not a lot of news on Christmas.
How do you fill a 10-minute newscast every hour?
Well, you know, it's an interesting thing.
Some years, there - you're right.
There isn't a lot of news.
Today was an interesting day because we had quite a few stories.
We had some really sad stories, of course, as we've seen through these days.
We had two significant bombings in Iraq that killed a lot of people.
We had some pretty rough weather in the Midwest and out in California.
But there are actually quite a number of stories to talk about most of the morning.
And of course, on Christmas Day, you have the pope speaking and giving his blessings.
There was an interesting story out of Bethlehem, I thought, this year, which was that tourists are starting to come back into old Bethlehem.
And they've really been absent since the second Palestinian uprising in 2000.
And with the peace process getting started again, all of a sudden there were more people in old Bethlehem.
